update.description:
This PR actually removes the built-in copy of urdfdom from sdformat.  Along the way, it also upgrades it to use urdfdom 1.0, which gets rid of a lot of boost in sdformat.  Note that the CI is going to fail for all of builds, since we need to update the infrastructure to have an external copy of urdfdom after this PR.  This should close out issue #110, at least.

Jose, I put you on this PR mostly to get some advice on how to start building/deploying stuff on the CI so we can get it to work.  Right now it looks like Linux is failing because pkg-config is not installed, OSX is failing because it can't find URDF 1.0, and Windows is failing because it can't find pkg-config.  That last one looks to be a cmake error, the rest are infrastructure problems.


* Start branch remove-boost-8

* Remove built-in copy of urdfdom.

    From now on, we'll use an external version.

* Make sdformat require urdfdom 0.3 or 0.4.

    That is, we remove the code that deals with urdfdom prior to 0.3.
    urdfdom *after* 0.4.2 requires a change in API which we aren't
    quite ready for, so for right now we restrict ourselves between
    0.3 and 0.4.

* Make sdformat require version 1.0 or later of urdfdom.

    This requires removing the boost code from parser_urdf.cc,
    and replacing with the std:: equivalent API that urdfdom 1.0
    exposes.
update.title: Remove boost 8

content.raw: Gentle ping; I have one "Approval" from Jose, I'm looking for one more so I can merge this and go on with more de-boostification.  Thanks!
content.html: Gentle ping; I have one "Approval" from Jose, I'm looking for one more so I can merge this and go on with more de-boostification. Thanks!

content.raw: you are right c3a7b38, [all is blue](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/224/). Ready to merge.
content.html: you are right c3a7b38, all is blue. Ready to merge.

content.raw: At least part of the problem there is that that Windows machine seems to have Python3 installed, and in Python3, "print foo" isn't allowed.  You have to do "print(foo)" instead.  Luckily, that is backwards compatible with Python2, so I might suggest just changing that script to do the latter, which should make it Python2/3 compatible.
content.html: At least part of the problem there is that that Windows machine seems to have Python3 installed, and in Python3, "print foo" isn't allowed. You have to do "print(foo)" instead. Luckily, that is backwards compatible with Python2, so I might suggest just changing that script to do the latter, which should make it Python2/3 compatible.

content.raw: I just remember that [we enable the psutil python module in Windows yesterday](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/issues/49/install-python-psutil-module-in-windows) and the error seems related. I'm in favour of merging the branch with the warning fixes and handle the test failure in a different PR.
content.html: I just remember that we enable the psutil python module in Windows yesterday and the error seems related. I'm in favour of merging the branch with the warning fixes and handle the test failure in a different PR.

[Xenial is now clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64/55/) and [Windows is happy too](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/222/). Unfortunately I see a new failing test in Windows, I'm investigating it.
content.html: I think I've killed all them in e4736cc (remove-boost-8_jrivero4 branch). Xenial is now clean and Windows is happy too. Unfortunately I see a new failing test in Windows, I'm investigating it.

content.raw: I see, looks good to me then. Whether we use the built-in version or the external one looks an implementation detail.
content.html: I see, looks good to me then. Whether we use the built-in version or the external one looks an implementation detail.

content.html: Well, urdfdom 1.0 is technically required everywhere; we will just use the built-in version of it to satisfy the dependency on Xenial and Windows. Any suggestions on how to word it better?

content.html: (except Ubuntu Xenial and Windows)?

content.raw:
I've created the branch `remove-boost-8_jrivero` with commits  d3ea33c and  257a6ce. The release-tools repo [will need changes](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/386/support-for-extra-cmake-in-urdfdom-on/diff) to be able to [compile it on Xenial](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64/49). The [Windows build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/208/console) is handled by the change in the configure.bat included in the branch. For brew we can use the internal or would be better to create the corresponding urdfdom formulas.

Please give it a try on Yakkety or Zesty before merging.
content.html:
I've created the branch remove-boost-8_jrivero with commits d3ea33c and 257a6ce. The release-tools repo will need changes to be able to compile it on Xenial. The Windows build is handled by the change in the configure.bat included in the branch. For brew we can use the internal or would be better to create the corresponding urdfdom formulas.

Please give it a try on Yakkety or Zesty before merging.

content.raw: ack. Almost all the PR needs to be redone, I'm on it.
content.html: ack. Almost all the PR needs to be redone, I'm on it.

content.raw: From a reviewing perspective, I think it would be easier to view the changes if we upgrade the fork of urdfdom in this same pull request, since currently all the files are deleted, then they will all be added back in the next one.
content.html: From a reviewing perspective, I think it would be easier to view the changes if we upgrade the fork of urdfdom in this same pull request, since currently all the files are deleted, then they will all be added back in the next one.

content.raw: Seems like we agree in the consensus of using an embedded urfdom 1.0 version to workaround the problems in Xenial and Windows. I would suggest to go ahead testing and approving this PR as it is now and I'm volunteer to implement the embed mechanism in a following PR.
content.html: Seems like we agree in the consensus of using an embedded urfdom 1.0 version to workaround the problems in Xenial and Windows. I would suggest to go ahead testing and approving this PR as it is now and I'm volunteer to implement the embed mechanism in a following PR.

content.raw: We could keep the status quo a little longer by updating the urdfdom fork to version 1.0. That seems easiest to me, as it resolves the xenial and windows build issues.
content.html: We could keep the status quo a little longer by updating the urdfdom fork to version 1.0. That seems easiest to me, as it resolves the xenial and windows build issues.

content.raw:
I see a couple of ways:

* Create an alternative urdfdom package and make sdformat to depend on it. In this case the creation of the library will expose the urdfdom symbols. There is a risk of mixing sdformat with other libraries in a Xenial system which uses the official urdfdom version supplied by Ubuntu.

* Embed a new copy of urdfdom 1.0 inside sdformat and use it to build the packages in Xenial. Do not require the urdfdom. The symbols are not exposed in the shared library. This is mostly the way it was working until this PR.

I assume that we don't want to drop the Xenial support in any way.
content.html:
I see a couple of ways:

  • Create an alternative urdfdom package and make sdformat to depend on it. In this case the creation of the library will expose the urdfdom symbols. There is a risk of mixing sdformat with other libraries in a Xenial system which uses the official urdfdom version supplied by Ubuntu.

  • Embed a new copy of urdfdom 1.0 inside sdformat and use it to build the packages in Xenial. Do not require the urdfdom. The symbols are not exposed in the shared library. This is mostly the way it was working until this PR.

I assume that we don't want to drop the Xenial support in any way.

content.raw: Agreed and I see the risks. Do we have other alternatives? Rename the custom urdfdom version?
content.html: Agreed and I see the risks. Do we have other alternatives? Rename the custom urdfdom version?

content.raw: side by side installations is a cool thing to have but a hell of effort to do it right. This is why the distributions discourage you when you try to get different version of the same software inside one distribution. We are not far with ignition libraries (I still need to submit the changes to enable inline namespaces which should avoid the ABIs problems) but I would prefer to keep urdfdom out of that approach.
content.html: side by side installations is a cool thing to have but a hell of effort to do it right. This is why the distributions discourage you when you try to get different version of the same software inside one distribution. We are not far with ignition libraries (I still need to submit the changes to enable inline namespaces which should avoid the ABIs problems) but I would prefer to keep urdfdom out of that approach.

content.raw: I'm starting to wonder whether the strategy of allowing side-by-side installations for ignition packages is worth the effort, giving the ABI problems we had with ignition math and the gazebo8 release. So I'm not sure.
content.html: I'm starting to wonder whether the strategy of allowing side-by-side installations for ignition packages is worth the effort, giving the ABI problems we had with ignition math and the gazebo8 release. So I'm not sure.

content.raw: Looks good to me besides a few minor comments. The code compiles and the tests pass. I saw a warning on `urdfdom` but we can track this separately. Ready to approve when we have consensus about how to proceed with the `urdfdom` dependencies.
content.html: Looks good to me besides a few minor comments. The code compiles and the tests pass. I saw a warning on urdfdom but we can track this separately. Ready to approve when we have consensus about how to proceed with the urdfdom dependencies.

content.raw: Could you update the `Changelog`?
content.html: Could you update the Changelog?

content.raw: Is this line needed? I don't see where we're linking with the URDF library in the tests.
content.html: Is this line needed? I don't see where we're linking with the URDF library in the tests.

content.raw: Can we modify urdfdom for allowing side by side installations with other major versions as we're doing with the Ignition libraries? If there are no major problems, we could release it as version 2.0.0. This pull request should try to find urdfdom 2.x first, and if not present, try to find 1.x. In Xenial, it should find our own hosted 2.0 version. In Yaketty we'll use the Ubuntu 1.x . At some point we should update Ubuntu to include version 2.x.
content.html: Can we modify urdfdom for allowing side by side installations with other major versions as we're doing with the Ignition libraries? If there are no major problems, we could release it as version 2.0.0. This pull request should try to find urdfdom 2.x first, and if not present, try to find 1.x. In Xenial, it should find our own hosted 2.0 version. In Yaketty we'll use the Ubuntu 1.x . At some point we should update Ubuntu to include version 2.x.

content.raw:
Some comments:

 * Xenial: we have some times in the past diverged from Ubuntu packages but the process is not trivial (we can not just upgrade the system package from our repository since it will break software built on top of the previous version), I would like to avoid this case if possible.
 * I can work on creating the `urdfdom` for Brew, no problem.
 * There is no `pkg-config` in Windows so the best option is to rely on the `cmake` module yes. I can help with the compilation of `urdfdom` in Windows.
content.html:
Some comments:

  • Xenial: we have some times in the past diverged from Ubuntu packages but the process is not trivial (we can not just upgrade the system package from our repository since it will break software built on top of the previous version), I would like to avoid this case if possible.
  • I can work on creating the urdfdom for Brew, no problem.
  • There is no pkg-config in Windows so the best option is to rely on the cmake module yes. I can help with the compilation of urdfdom in Windows.

content.raw:
Right, I was looking a bit at those problems.

* For xenial, we'll either have to ship our own package, or require a build from source of urdfdom 1.0.
* The mac homebrew one we'll have to make, as you say.
* For Windows, I think we'll probably want to make urdfdom discoverable via cmake (find_package), but I've been having trouble compiling urdfdom on Windows at all.  I'll poke at it some more when I get some free cycles again.

I knew that all of these were going to be issues with this, which is why I wanted to get started :).
content.html:
Right, I was looking a bit at those problems.

  • For xenial, we'll either have to ship our own package, or require a build from source of urdfdom 1.0.
  • The mac homebrew one we'll have to make, as you say.
  • For Windows, I think we'll probably want to make urdfdom discoverable via cmake (find_package), but I've been having trouble compiling urdfdom on Windows at all. I'll poke at it some more when I get some free cycles again.

I knew that all of these were going to be issues with this, which is why I wanted to get started :).

content.raw:
As the CI failures indicate, we need to consider platform availability of urdfdom 1.0 before merging this:

* xenial only has urdfdom 0.4, though yakkety/zesty have urdfdom 1.0
* the mac homebrew formula doesn't depend on an external urdfdom by default. We should create a urdfdom 1.0 formula and change the dependency in order to support this PR
* the internal fork of urdfdom is most helpful on windows where it is more difficult to resolve dependencies. also, we need an alternative to `pkg-config` if we want windows to be able to find an external urdfdom
content.html:
As the CI failures indicate, we need to consider platform availability of urdfdom 1.0 before merging this:

  • xenial only has urdfdom 0.4, though yakkety/zesty have urdfdom 1.0
  • the mac homebrew formula doesn't depend on an external urdfdom by default. We should create a urdfdom 1.0 formula and change the dependency in order to support this PR
  • the internal fork of urdfdom is most helpful on windows where it is more difficult to resolve dependencies. also, we need an alternative to pkg-config if we want windows to be able to find an external urdfdom

update.description:
This PR actually removes the built-in copy of urdfdom from sdformat.  Along the way, it also upgrades it to use urdfdom 1.0, which gets rid of a lot of boost in sdformat.  Note that the CI is going to fail for all of builds, since we need to update the infrastructure to have an external copy of urdfdom after this PR.  This should close out issue #110, at least.

Jose, I put you on this PR mostly to get some advice on how to start building/deploying stuff on the CI so we can get it to work.  Right now it looks like Linux is failing because pkg-config is not installed, OSX is failing because it can't find URDF 1.0, and Windows is failing because it can't find pkg-config.  That last one looks to be a cmake error, the rest are infrastructure problems.


* Start branch remove-boost-8

* Remove built-in copy of urdfdom.

    From now on, we'll use an external version.

* Make sdformat require urdfdom 0.3 or 0.4.

    That is, we remove the code that deals with urdfdom prior to 0.3.
    urdfdom *after* 0.4.2 requires a change in API which we aren't
    quite ready for, so for right now we restrict ourselves between
    0.3 and 0.4.

* Make sdformat require version 1.0 or later of urdfdom.

    This requires removing the boost code from parser_urdf.cc,
    and replacing with the std:: equivalent API that urdfdom 1.0
    exposes.
update.title: Remove boost 8
